questions.question: Which one of these is NOT a full operating system?
options: Linux
Windows NT
MS-DOS
FreeBSD
Oracle Solaris
questions._comment: Linux is a kernel, the OS is usually called GNU/Linux.

questions.question:
What does this linux shell command do?
sudo dd if=/dev/urandom of=/dev/sda bs=1M status=progress
options: Copies random data to the hard drive, effectively destroying all data
Creates a backup of the hard drive to a file
Formats the hard drive to prepare it for a new OS installation
Scans the hard drive for errors and bad sectors
Encrypts the hard drive using random keys
questions._comment: /dev/urandom is a special file that provides random data. /dev/sda is usually the main hard drive.

questions.question: What is cache memory?
options: A smaller memory to hold temporary values from RAM that are used frequently
A brand of smartphones that have more memory than usual
A slower memory used to hold big files that can't fit in RAM
A persistent storage like an HD or SSD
A backup memory that stores data when the computer is turned off

questions.question: <answer> is 123 in hexadecimal.
options: 0x7B
0x2C7
0xAB

questions.question: Which of these algorithms is better for sorting integer arrays?
options: Counting Sort
Radix Sort
Quick Sort
Bubble Sort
Linked Lists

questions.question: In the internet, what does DNS stand for?
options: Domain Name System
Data Network Service
Digital Numbering System
Dangerous Nuclear Substances
Distributed Network Security

questions.question: Who was Alan Turing?
options: An english computer scientist who played a key role in breaking the Enigma code during World War II
An australian former hacker and activist who founded the WikiLeaks website, exposing classified government information
An english mathematician often regarded as the first computer programmer for working on the first proposed mechanical computer
A serbian-american inventor and engineer, known for his contributions to the development of alternating current (AC) electrical systems
An american software freedom activist and programmer, known for founding the Free Software Foundation and developing the GNU Project
questions._comment: 2 is Julian Assange, 3 is Ada Lovelace, 4 is Nikola Tesla, 5 is Richard Stallman.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'return' statement in a function?
options: To send a value back to the caller of the function
To exit the program
To print a value to the console
To go back to a previous command
To return the value to the operating system

questions.question: Which of the following data structures uses FIFO (First In, First Out) principle?
options: Queue
Linked List
Stack
Binary Tree
Trash Can

questions.question: In object-oriented programming, what does inheritance allow a class to do?
options: Reuse methods and properties of another class
Inherit the money and goods of its parents
Create multiple instances of the same class
Keep elements of the class private
To have functions with the same name but different parameters

questions.question: What is a 'syscall'?
options: A system call that allows programs to request services from the operating system
A type of malware that infects the system by calling many processes
A system used to make calls using a SIM card
A software to call system administrators for help
A network protocol for making secure calls between systems

questions.question: A <answer> encrypts your internet traffic and hides your IP address by routing it through multiple volunteer-operated servers.
options: Tor Network
VPN
Proxy
Firewall
Router
questions._comment: A VPN connection passes your traffic through a single centralized server, while Tor uses multiple decentralized nodes.

questions.question: What is the site 'thepiratebay.org' known for?
options: Being a popular torrent site for sharing pirated content
A multiplayer web game with battles between pirate ships
A legal streaming service for pirate-themed movies and shows
Hosting information about historic facts related to pirates
Offering cloud storage services

questions.question: In cybersecurity, what does the term 'phishing' refer to?
options: A cyber attack that tricks individuals into providing sensitive information
A technique used to catch fish using electronic devices
A method of encrypting data for secure transmission
A software that protects against malware, catching them like fish in a net
A type of firewall configuration

questions.question: What are the most common http requests?
options: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE
OPEN, CLOSE, READ, WRITE
START, STOP, PAUSE, RESUME
FETCH, SEND, RECEIVE, UPDATE
HALT, TRANSFER, TAKE, POSTPONE

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a relational database?
options: It organizes data into tables with rows and columns
It stores data in key-value pairs
It uses a tree-like structure to store data
It is designed for unstructured data like images and videos
It does not support complex queries
